metadata.excerpt: There’s much to celebrate about the 1990s, but in many ways 1997, whose 25th birthday we toast in this issue, is the ninetiest moment of all the 1990s. The year not only embodies what we love most about this crazy decade—boy bands! girl groups! Monica and Ross!—it laid the groundwork for trends that are still playing out today. Consider the singing confection called the Spice Girls. At first glance Ginger, Posh, Scary, Baby and Sporty were a fun, fizzy antidote to the early-’90s grunge sound. But the Spices also represented a bigger picture: They were intentionally different in looks, dress and archetypes long before diverse became a buzzword, and they previewed the power tipping toward women in pop and mainstream culture. Then there was the Hollywood tidal wave Titanic. At a cost of $200 million, the disaster epic both busted budget norms and redefined box office expectations—it was the first flick to break the billion-dollar mark in ticket sales—all while buoying the movie biz and throwing open the world of special effects. Another defining moment of 1997 was the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, in August. A shocked world mourned her passing but also watched as the loss set in motion events that shaped Buckingham Palace today. Future monarch Prince William and his wife, Kate Middleton, are closely carrying on Diana’s legacy at home while the princess’s younger son Prince Harry and wife Meghan Markle have put an ocean between themselves and the intense scrutiny of full-time royal life. So many more of the year’s changes touch our lives daily: Steve Jobs returned to Apple launching a decade of innovation that gave us the iPhone. In September two Stanford grad students registered a domain name for an algorithm that could search the internet for Web pages and rank them in terms of traffic. (Can’t remember what it was called? Google it.) So, yes, 1997 deserves a special celebration. It both encapsulated the decade and set the tone for the one to come.

components.text: here’s much to celebrate about the 1990s, but in many ways 1997, whose 25th birthday we toast in this issue, is the ninetiest moment of all the 1990s. The year not only embodies what we love most about this crazy decade—boy bands! girl groups! Monica and Ross!—it laid the groundwork for trends that are still playing out today. Consider the singing confection called the Spice Girls. At first glance Ginger, Posh, Scary, Baby and Sporty were a fun, fizzy antidote to the early-’90s grunge sound. But the Spices also represented a bigger picture: They were intentionally different in looks, dress and archetypes long before diverse became a buzzword, and they previewed the power tipping toward women in pop and mainstream culture. Then there was the Hollywood tidal wave Titanic. At a cost of $200 million, the disaster epic both busted budget norms and redefined box office expectations—it was the first flick to break the billion-dollar mark in ticket sales—all while buoying the movie biz and throwing open the world of special effects. Another defining moment of 1997 was the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, in August. A shocked world mourned her passing but also watched as the loss set in motion events that shaped Buckingham Palace today. Future monarch Prince William and his wife, Kate Middleton, are closely carrying on Diana’s legacy at home while the princess’s younger son Prince Harry and wife Meghan Markle have put an ocean between themselves and the intense scrutiny of full-time royal life. So many more of the year’s changes touch our lives daily: Steve Jobs returned to Apple launching a decade of innovation that gave us the iPhone. In September two Stanford grad students registered a domain name for an algorithm that could search the internet for Web pages and rank them in terms of traffic. (Can’t remember what it was called? Google it.) So, yes, 1997 deserves a special celebration. It both encapsulated the decade and set the tone for the one to come.

Lasting Impact
Who knew that 25 years on we’d still be talking about many of the events and people that shaped 1997? But the year was a big one, with stories that warmed our hearts (the McCaughey septuplets) and that broke them (JonBenét Ramsey); that fascinated (Brad and Gwyneth) and inspired (21-year-old Tiger Woods winning the Masters).
